channel.title: World
channel.description: The Washington Post World section provides information and analysis of breaking world news stories. In addition to our world news and video, Post World News offers discussions and blogs on major international news and economic issues.

item.title: Live updates: Israel carries out strike in Beirut suburb targeting key Hezbollah leader, military says
item.dc:creator: Victoria Bisset, Andrew Jeong, Sammy Westfall, Louisa Loveluck
item.description: The target was Ibrahim Aqil, a prominent Hezbollah leader, according to Israel’s Army Radio and Israeli officials familiar with the operation.

item.dc:creator: Louisa Loveluck, Victoria Bisset, Mohamad El Chamaa

item.title: National security spokesman Kirby was ‘not aware of any pre-notification’ of strikes
item.dc:creator: Karen DeYoung, Sammy Westfall

item.title: Israel targets senior Hezbollah commander in Beirut suburb
item.dc:creator: Louisa Loveluck, Victoria Bisset, Mohamad El Chamaa
item.description: The strike targeted prominent Hezbollah leader Ibrahim Aqil, Israeli officials said.

item.title: Israel carries out ‘targeted’ strike in Beirut suburb, military says
item.dc:creator: Suzy Haidamous, Louisa Loveluck, Mohamad El Chamaa, Sammy Westfall

item.title: E.U. to loan Ukraine up to $39 billion backed by frozen Russian assets
item.dc:creator: Ellen Francis, Beatriz Ríos
item.description: G-7 nations had promised Ukraine at least $50 billion using frozen Russian assets, but there were differences between the United States and the European Union over implementation.

item.title: Israel and Hezbollah exchange fire as tensions escalate on Lebanon border
item.dc:creator: Victoria Bisset, Andrew Jeong

item.title: Israel’s clash with Hezbollah strains U.S. effort to prevent wider war
item.dc:creator: John Hudson

item.title: Pagers attack brings to life long-feared supply chain threat
item.dc:creator: Eva Dou, Gerrit De Vynck

item.title: Taiwan says exploding pagers not produced there; Japanese company probes walkie-talkies
item.dc:creator: Julia Mio Inuma, Vic Chiang

item.title: Women’s soccer players, muscled and sweaty, are a new kind of influencer
item.dc:creator: Lorena Rios, Verónica Gabriela Cárdenas
item.description: Mexican soccer players are attracting millions of social media followers while challenging gender norms in the traditionally macho country.

item.title: Washington and the West struggle for a way forward with Putin’s Russia
item.dc:creator: Robyn Dixon, Michael Birnbaum
item.description: In the United States and Europe, there is growing uncertainty about how to counter Putin’s aggression without stoking a direct conflict with Russia.

item.title: Video: What we know about Israeli attacks on Hezbollah devices
item.dc:creator: Joe Snell, Shane Harris

item.title: The Chinese economy is faltering — and that means more trade tensions
item.dc:creator: Katrina Northrop
item.description: Growth in the world’s second-largest economy is slowing and stock markets are in decline, but the Chinese government remains reluctant to act.

item.title: Hezbollah chief calls pager, radio attacks an ‘act of war’ by Israel
item.dc:creator: Claire Parker, Mohamad El Chamaa, Lior Soroka, Shira Rubin

item.title: Toll of Lebanon device attacks reveals Hezbollah’s ‘society in arms’
item.dc:creator: Susannah George, Suzan Haidamous

item.dc:creator: Loveday Morris, Joby Warrick, Shira Rubin

item.title: A broader Israel-Lebanon war now seems inevitable
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor
item.description: This week’s pager explosions in Lebanon represent a tactical victory for Israel. They also appear likely to lock the region into an escalatory spiral.

item.title: What to know about Hezbollah, the Lebanese group hit by pager blasts
item.dc:creator: Anika Seth, Adam Taylor
item.description: Israeli leaders have said they did not want to escalate the conflict with the Lebanese group. They also said they were ready for any scenario.

item.title: Israel’s clash with Hezbollah strains U.S. effort to prevent wider war
item.dc:creator: John Hudson
item.description: The absence of a full-blown war in Lebanon has been touted as a core U.S. achievement, but now Washington’s grip on the crisis appears more tenuous than ever.

item.title: Exploding pager attacks in Lebanon, and fears of a wider war
item.dc:creator: Rennie Svirnovskiy, Monica Campbell, Emma Talkoff, Bishop Sand, Ted Muldoon
item.description: Hezbollah’s leader called two days of deadly blasts in Lebanon this week an “act of war” by Israel. Today, on “Post Reports,” what we know about how the attacks unfolded – and whether they could escalate to all-out war.

item.title: Toll of Lebanon device attacks reveals Hezbollah’s ‘society in arms’
item.dc:creator: Susannah George, Suzan Haidamous
item.description: The attacks offer a rare window into the inner workings of Hezbollah — an organization that is notoriously secretive and deeply embedded in Lebanese society.

item.title: Hezbollah chief calls pager, radio attacks an ‘act of war’ by Israel
item.dc:creator: Claire Parker, Mohamad El Chamaa, Lior Soroka, Shira Rubin
item.description: Hezbollah leader Hasan Nasrallah addressed the nation Thursday in a televised speech, as Israeli warplanes flew over the Lebanese capital, Beirut.

item.title: Mohamed al-Fayed, billionaire and friend of U.K. royalty, accused of rape
item.dc:creator: Karla Adam
item.description: The 20 accusers include five women who said he assaulted them while they worked at Harrods, the high-end London store he owned. He died in 2023.

item.title: Japanese walkie-talkie maker investigating Lebanon explosion reports
item.dc:creator: Julia Mio Inuma
item.description: Icom says the two-way radios apparently used in deadly attacks across Lebanon were discontinued a decade ago.

item.title: Portugal wracked by blazes at tail end of Europe’s wildfire season
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch
item.description: Three firefighters died battling the blazes, Portugal’s prime minister said, adding the country was going through “difficult days.”

item.title: Sword with pharaoh’s mark found in Egypt, still shimmering 3,000 years later
item.dc:creator: Leo Sands
item.description: The bronze sword was unearthed by archaeologists at an ancient fort in the Nile Delta. It was emblazoned with the signature emblem of Ancient Egyptian pharaoh Ramses II.

item.title: Woman spends almost two hours in 13-foot python’s coils: ‘I fought with it’
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Hassan
item.description: Thai rescue workers freed the woman, who had been washing dishes at home when she was trapped by the 13-foot python. She was bitten several times.

item.title: A key question behind Israeli attack on Hezbollah devices: Why now?
item.dc:creator: Loveday Morris, Joby Warrick, Shira Rubin
item.description: Israel’s government is in turmoil and the United States is trying to head off a wider conflict in Lebanon, leaving officials to wonder about the timing of the attack.

item.title: Putin wants Russia’s youth to become ultranationalist patriots. Many are all in.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Ebel
item.description: Young Russians are embracing Kremlin propaganda, reshaping the Ukraine war narrative with ultranationalist views and seeing themselves as patriotic truth defenders.

item.title: U.N. General Assembly demands Israel end occupation of Palestinian territory
item.dc:creator: Niha Masih
item.description: The nonbinding resolution says Israel must end its “unlawful presence” within a year, pull out military forces, halt settlement expansion and evacuate settlers.

item.title: Lost for 450 years, famed poet’s grave found at Notre Dame, scientists say
item.dc:creator: Praveena Somasundaram
item.description: Researchers believe the remains found in a lead coffin in 2022 are those of the French Renaissance poet Joachim du Bellay.

item.title: New explosions kill 20 in Lebanon a day after pager attack
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch
item.description: Additional explosions linked to electronic devices caused more deaths and injuries a day after pagers used by Hezbollah exploded, wounding thousands.

item.title: Wednesday blasts in Lebanon appeared to cause more damage than first attack
item.dc:creator: Meg Kelly, Evan Hill

item.title: Antiwar film or propaganda? ‘Russians at War’ draws protests at festivals.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Coletta, Jada Yuan
item.description: The documentary focuses on front-line Russian troops in Ukraine. Screenings at the Toronto International Film Festival drew concerns from Canadian officials.

item.dc:creator: Gerrit De Vynck, Sammy Westfall, Elizabeth Dwoskin, Niha Masih
item.description: The scale of an apparent attack targeting thousands of Hezbollah members across Lebanon at the same time, using their own devices, is unprecedented.

item.description: The pagers, deemed by Hezbollah to be safer than cellphones, were probably rigged with explosives before they were delivered to Lebanon, experts said.

item.title: Lebanon reels as more devices explode, casualties rise

item.description: The source of Wednesday’s explosions was not immediately clear, but the blasts came a day after thousands of pagers used by Hezbollah blew up across Lebanon.
